user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of alloc:
```c
static int alloc(void)
{
	void *ptr;

	ptr = metal_allocate_memory(1000);
	if (!ptr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "failed to allocate memory\n");
		return errno;
	}

	metal_free_memory(ptr);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function alloc:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The macro expands to a GNU statement-expression containing a single conditional call: if(_metal.common.log_handler && level <= _metal.common.log_level) _metal.common.log_handler(...); There is no code that can never be reached at compile time — the call is executed only when the condition is true, otherwise the if-body is simply not taken at runtime. Therefore no unreachable code is present in this fragment. (Note: the use of GNU statement-expressions and variadic macro extensions may raise other MISRA concerns, but they do not create unreachable code for Rule 2.1.)
